title: sue grays report downing street
story: When is Sue Grays report into Downing Street party allegations due Despite concerns over the independence of the investigation, attention is now focusing on the findings of Sue Gray and her team regarding the parties alleged to have taken place in Downing Street during lockdown involving Boris Johnson and his staffJohnson finds MPs baying for blood on both sides of the aisle Image: REUTERSByHarry Thompson:,  Jan | comments The temperature is rising for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as the jaw-dropping Partygate scandal continues to rage, leaving him faced with disregard on both sides of the aisle. The national leaderaposs alleged contempt for the rules put in place to help prevent the spread of coronavirus across the past two years has caused fury throughout the nation.In response to the frustration - which stems from millions of Brits making huge sacrices, including not being able to be with elderly loved ones - an investigation has been launched into the string of gatherings. At the helm of investigation sits Sue Gray, the most powerful person youaposve never heard of. Who is Sue Gray   Senior civil servant Sue Gray served as Director General of Propriety and Ethics in the Cabinet Office between  and .Before this, she worked in the departments of Transport, Health and Work and Pensions. After these roles, she took a career break in the late s to run a pub in Northern Ireland before joining the Cabinet Office in the s.She now holds the role of the Second Permanent Secretary to the Cabinet Office, a role charged with leading on the Union and the Constitution.When is the Sue Gray report into Downing Street party allegations   The report is expected towards the end of this week or early next - the exact date remains to be confirmed. The reason no one has any hard and fast answers about the reportaposs release date stems from the additional revelations cropping up about more parties alleged to have taken place. What does the Sue Gray investigation cover   The primary purpose of Grayaposs report is, according to the Cabinet Office, to: Establish swtly a general understanding of the nature of the gatherings, including attendance, the setting and the purpose, with reference to adherence to the guidance in place at the time.The scope of the report initially set out to cover the Downing Street Christmas parties on November  and December , but the number of dates under the microscope has now been extended to include two parties that took place on the night before Prince Philipaposs funeral on April . According to the terms of reference set out for the investigation: Where there are credible allegations relating to other gatherings, these may be investigated.They also state that: If required, the investigations will establish whether inidual disciplinary action is warranted. The terms set out that investigators will have access to documents and will be able to speak to staff throughout its course. Is the Sue Gray investigation independent  One key concern remains, however, about the independence of the investigation. This is because despite being at the heart of Grayaposs explorations, Boris Johnson is also the person who gets to decidethe next stage of the investigation can actually go ahead.After Grayaposs report, Johnson will have the final say as to whether the Prime Minister’s advisor on ministerial interests, Lord Geidt, can actually start an investigation into any breaches of ministerial code.Speaking on the matter, Angela Rayner, the deputy Labour leader, said: “The PM has set the terms of Sue Gray’s probe and he has chosen to exclude the conduct of Ministers from it, creating a neat loophole for himself.“Any judgement on the conduct of Boris Johnson goes to... Boris Johnson. “A farcical circular process from a Prime Minister that will escape responsibility in any way he can. title: there no hope prime minister
story: There is no hope for mocked and ridiculed Prime Minister who leads by the fringeI never bought the Johnson appeal but I understood why many voters did - now his political obituaries are being written, writes Kevin MaguireThe despised Downing St party liar Boris Johnson’s authority has gone for good Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMercilessly mocked and ridiculed, the despised Downing St party liar Boris Johnson’s authority has gone for good. No Prime Minister is able to survive for long in high office when they trigger scorn in every home, workplace, cafe and pub. A mate of mine, a retired welder in a red wall seat, sent a reworking of a joke about a dead man at the Pearly Gates and was informed by St Peter the hands on heavenly lie clocks ticked only when fibs were heard. The pointers on those of Mother Theresa, Abraham Lincoln and Nelson Mandela had never moved. “Where’s Boris Johnson’s clock ” inquired the man. “We’re using it as a ceiling fan,” replied St Peter. Sacricing the jobs of Downing Street staff to save his own skin will not work for Johnson. It feels like when nothe is booted out of No  by Tory MPs worried about their futures. Nor is he able to cower in a fridge again as the glass door on the front of No ’s wine-time Friday cooler symbolises the charlatan having hidden in plain sight for too long.  Suitcases of booze smuggled into Downing Street, drunken shenanigans on the eve of the Duke of Edinburgh’s funeral and an unprecedented apology to Buckingham Palace have a last days of Rome vibe to them. Labour leads of up to % in the polls are encouraging the opposition to go for the jugular, Keir Starmer justiably accusing the PM of breaking the law and lying. With jilted insider Dominic Cummings orchestrating much of the onslaught, there’s an irony in Johnson as co-author of his own downfall. Labour is aware it should target the Tories as much as Johnson himself when as rising star Wes Streeting acknowledged, the opposition’s best bet’s a mortally wounded PM limping on or the Conservatives will claim they have changed under Rishi Sunak or Liz Truss.What do you think  Have your say in the comments below.From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  They successfully played the trick in Government when John Major succeeded Margaret Thatcher, Theresa May followed David Cameron then Johnson came after May. I never bought the Johnson appeal but I understood why many voters did. Brexit, his main pitch, was another lie and anyway even many who wanted to quit the European Union these days avoid talking about the mess. Whatever magic Johnson displayed is gone and isn’t ing. The steady drip of awful rule-breaking, civil servant Sue Gray’s party report, April’s tax rises and soaring energy bills and May’s local elections all threaten fresh blows for a deflated egotist who cut a beaten figure on the ropes at Prime Minister’s Questions. Lting England’s Covid restrictions will earn little credit when he’s lost credibility. Johnson’s political obituaries are being written. Only the publication date is to be decided. History will be justiably unkind to a truly terrible leader. title: what pork pie plot dozens
story: What is the Pork Pie Plot as dozens of Tory MPs turn on Boris Johnson over PartygateScores of Tory MPs from the  intake have turned on Boris Johnson over Partygate. Heres what you need to know about the Pork Pie Plot as MPs conspire over Johnsons futureBoris Johnson could soon be facing a vote of confidence from his MPs Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan | commentsBoris Johnsonaposs premiership is at risk like never before as over a dozen Tory MPs from the  election are said to be furious at the Prime Minister for his handling of the Partygate scandal.The MPs are reportedly preparing to submit their letters of no confidence to the chairman of the  Committee of backbench MPs, Sir Graham Brady - and some are believed to have already written in.Reports suggest that the  letters will reach Sir Graham by Wednesday, January , which means Johnson could be facing a vote of no confidence soon after.Hereaposs everything you need to know about the conspiratorial aposPork Pie Plotapos, which Tory MPs have publicly called for the Prime Minister to resign and whataposs likely to happen next.What is the Pork Pie Plot about  More than  Tory MPs who won seats in the ‘Red Wall’ - a number of constituencies in northern England that had typically voted Labour until the  election - are said to have met on Tuesday, January  to discuss Johnsonaposs future as Prime Minister.The gathering was nicknamed the “Pork Pie Plot” or the “Pork Pie Putsch” as it was hosted by MP for Rutland and Melton Alicia Kearns - and Melton is the town best known for its pork pies. Some of the plotters include Bishop Auckland MP Dehenna Davison Chris Loder, who hosted the group’s last meeting Gary Sambrook , the first Tory to hold Birmingham Northfield since , as well as Bury South MP Christian Wakeford, who is best-known for cursing at scandal-hit colleague Owen Paterson in the Commons.Who has called for the Prime Minister to resign  Seven Tory MPs have publicly called for Johnsonaposs resignation. Wakeford – who has a majority of just  – was the latest to make the call for the Prime Minister to resign on Tuesday. He then defected to Labour just before Wednesdayaposs Prime Ministeraposs Questions, citing Johnson as incapable of offering the leadership and government this country deserves. Though only a handful of Tories have publicly called for his resignation, several of them are believed to be furious over Johnsonaposs handling of the Partygate scandal. They were angered further by the PMaposs statement that nobody told him that the party at Downing Street was a violation of the country-wide rules he himself had set.Whataposs likely to happen next  An inquiry into the Downing Street parties, led by senior civil servant Sue Gray, is expected to be published on either Friday or early next week.Some MPs are reported to be waiting for Ms Gray’s findings before deciding on submitting a letter to Sir Graham. If the  letters needed to trigger a no confidence vote is reached, the next step will see Tory MPs voting on whether they have confidence in in the Prime Minister. Johnson will need % or more of MPs to back him or end up losing his position. If he does end up winning, then the MPs will be barred from forcing another vote on his premiership for the next  months. story: Boys left feeling uncomfortable after school removes toilet doorsBoys at Range High School, in Formby, have complained of being "uncomfortable" using toilets after doors have been removed due to "anti-social behaviour" and say it is an invasion of their privacyBoys toilet doors have been removed at Range High School, in FormbyByJonathan HumphriesTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments Boys at a school are unhappy that doors from the toilets have been removed and it has left them feeling uncomfortable using them. The decision was taken at Range High School in Formby to remove the doors over the Christmas half-term over what has been called anti-social behaviour, reported the Liverpool Echo.But no changes have been made to the girlsapos toilets where the doors remain. One Year  pupil at the school said that he doesnapost like the way people can now hear them using the toilet from outside. He said: People donapost feel comfortable using the toilets.  There are cubicles, but the urinals are behind a screen and you can see into the room and hear people using the toilets. Itaposs just created tension in the school. It happened to me yesterday, I was using the toilet and there were some girls outside, and as I was coming out they shouted aposwe can hear youapos. Itaposs not a comfortable experience. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  The student also said he did not think it was fair for only the boysapos toilets to be targeted in this way and yet the girlsapos still have doors. He said: I donapost think the girls should have their doors removed but for me you should either do it to both or not at all. I donapost understand why. You will get a dferent answer depending on who you ask. One said because of anti-social behaviour, another said to improve ventilation. Tom Dolly, deputy headteacher at Range High School, told the Liverpool Echo that it was decided to remove the doors due to anti-social behaviour, and he denied that the boysapos privacy is affected. He said: Following some anti-social behaviour in certain boysapos toilets, the school has refurbished and upgraded some of the facilities as part of an ongoing improvement agenda and as requested by the school student council. No oneaposs privacy is compromised in any way following the installation of new privacy ling in the two toilets where doors have been removed. There are also many other toilets across the school for students to access. news uk-news covid-lateral-flow-tests-less-"Covid restrictions may be ‘substantially’ reduced next week says JavidByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsCovid lateral flow tests don’t work as well on children, according to a new study.A team of British and German scientists have pooled together results from  old studies, involving over , kids, to examine the efficacy of lateral flows in detecting Covid amongst young people. Writing in the British Medical Journal, their study claims that the rapid kits were not as effective in youngsters and students, even as all secondary school students in Britain are encouraged to use them twice weekly. Their findings said that the tests only detected  per cent of Covid positive children. When the children had symptoms of Covid, like a cough or change or loss to the sense of taste and smell, detection rates increased to  per cent.  This means only little over half the youngsters who had the virus were caught. The authors said their findings meant that lateral flow tests would fail to meet the minimum standards of the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, the US’ Food and Drug Administration and the World Health Organisation. These three bodies all require Covid testing kits to meet a minimum of around an  per cent success rate.  The study only included samples taken by professionally trained iniduals and not self testing at home.This comes as Omicron cases continue to fall, day-on-day, amidst hopes the fourth waves has peaked.One of the authors, Dr Naomi Fujita-Rohwerder, of the Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care in Cologne, Germany, said: “Taking into account test-specic pooled results, no test included in this review fully satisfied the minimum performance requirements as recommended by WHO...the US…or the MHRA in the UK.  “This may affect the planned purpose of the broad implementation of testing programmes.” The report only examined studies that used eight dferent lateral flow kits, so some of the + tests available globally may be more accurate. All of the studie looked at in the new analysis were published between the start of  and May  meaning they will not have contained the Omicron iant.  The researchers did not offer any reasons why the tests had performed less accurately on children, or a comparative study in adults. Regular and freely available lateral flow tests are a key part of the UK’s response to Covid and containing it. title: dairylea advert girls eating cheese
story: Dairylea advert of girls eating cheese upside down banned for choking riskA Dairylea advert featuring two girls eating cheese triangles upside down has been banned after complaints that it was promoting unsafe behaviour and that kids could chokeA Dairylea cheese advert has been banned Image: Anita Maric   SWNSByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsComplaints over an advert showing two girls eating Dairylea cheese triangles upside down has led to it being banned for encouraging aposunsafe behaviour.apos The authority stepped in after reports of one person saying their three-year-old relative had tried to copy them.People had reported the video, seen on ITV Hub, All  and My  in August, as they claimed other kids could copy them and end up choking. There were  viewers who felt that the girls hanging upside down from a football goal before one opened the cheese snack and ate it, condoned or encouraged behaviour that could be dangerouschildren copied it.Dairylea owner Mondelez UK said the adaposs purpose was to show parents allowing their children more freedom and the video included two supervising parents in the background.  Mondelez referred to a study that they said supported their view that a personaposs ability to swallow was not affected by the position they ate in, including when eating upside down. Based on the research, and because Dairylea was a soft food, they considered there was a very low risk of choking when eating upside down. The ad had also been given an ex-kids scheduling restriction, but Mondelez said they were no longer running it and would remove references to eating upside downthey used it in future. The Advertising Standards Authoritysaid it sought advice from the Child Accident Prevention Trust, whose view was that the scenario depicted in the ad represented a situation where there was potentially a high risk of choking. The ASA also noted that one complainant had reported that their three-year-old relative, after seeing the advert, ate their food whilst hanging upside down. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  The ASA said: We therefore considered that eating whilst upside down was an unsafe practice and one which could be dangerous for children to emulate. We therefore concluded that a scheduling restriction was not sufficient to reduce the risk of harm and that the ad breached the Code. The ASA ruled that the ad must not appear again, adding: We told Mondelez UK to ensure their advertising did not condone or encourage unsafe practices. A Mondelez spokesman said: We recognise and will abide by the ASAaposs decision but we are disappointed by the ruling. We carefully consulted with Clearcast to pre-approve the content of this video on demand advert prior to airing. It was aimed at adultsrather than young children and was deliberately scheduled away from programming likely to appeal to children under . As such, we believe it was unlikely to encourage aposcopycatapos behaviour by young children. We remain committed to responsible advertising and work with a range of partners to make sure our marketing meets and complies with all relevant UK regulations. title: grieving pensioner left cashless after
story: Exclusive: Grieving pensioner left cashless after computer glitch shuts down her bank accountsJacqueline Sievewright has had to borrow money from her elderly mother after Halax shut down all of her bank accounts and cancelled all of her credit and debit cards following the death of her husbandJacqueline Sievewright was suddenly left cashless Image: Ben Lack Photography LtdByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA grieving pensioner has been left cashless and feeling suicidal after all her bank accounts were closed mysteriously. In the days after Christmas, Jacqueline Sievewright discovered that all her debit and credit cards were no longer working and that she didnapost have a ing bank account. The baffled -year-old borrowed money from her -year-old mum before getting hold of someone at Halax, which sheaposd banked with for years. An operator told her her both her inidual and joint accounts had been closed due to a computer glitch following the death of her husband Francis, who died of pancreatic cancer in October. Despite spending days frantically trying to sort out the issue, cash transfers and direct debits are still bouncing off of Jacquelineaposs frozen accounts. They blocked everything. My credit card, direct debits, standing orders, state pension and private pension was rejected, and money coming in, the Immingham, Lincolnshire woman told the Mirror. I am still grieving. Last Thursday everything just got on top of me. For two days I just cried and cried. I was so low I felt like ending it all. Jacqueline first knew something was amiss the week after Christmas, when her mumaposs attempts to transfer money into her bank account failed. When the former Norfolk County Council worker tried to log in to her online account, it told her she wasnapost registered. She called Halax where an operator explained that the issue was not due to a human error, but a computer glitch. Jacqueline then embarked on several days of calling the bank and sending in her husbandaposs death certicate in a fruitless bid to get the accounts brought back online. She later received a call from Halax telling her requesting a money from a branch would be pointless and that her complaint, despite being unresolved, had been closed internally. I canapost just rely on my -year-old mum for money, Jacqueline said. I spent two days from am to pm ringing round  dferent companies resetting direct debits and informing them of the change of circumstances. I then reinstated two dormant accounts with Natwest and HSBC so I could do some shopping. Two weeks on, Jacquelineaposs accounts have suddenly been reinstated by Halax, which sent her flowers as an apology. The confusing situation has been particularly dficult for Jacqueline as she recently lost her husband Francis. The retired banker fell ill in February last year and was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. In the eight months before he died in October, he spent five and a half in hospital. Jacqueline was able to bring him home from hospital to be with her in his final days. A Lloyds Bank spokesperson said: “We were so sorry to hear of Mrs Sievewright’s loss and the experience she had when she got in touch. Mrs Sievewright’s accounts are up and running again, we’ve provided training and feedback to our team, and we’ll be getting in touch with her to put things right.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NatWestHalax Inc.HSBCBanksHospitalsPensionsCredit cardsState pensionComputers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Inside terrible tiny house on sale for £K which makes people feel queasyThe quirky property is on sale in Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester for £, - but its staircase is half-sized and its kitchen minusculeThis tiny house in Greater Manchester is causing quite a stir online Image: RightmoveByEthan DaviesLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Jan | comments An unusual property on sale in Greater Manchester has caused a stir online with its minuscule proportions. The surprising one-bedroom home located near the town centre of Ramsbottom in Manchester is being listed for £, - and is worthy of George Clarke aposs Amazing Spaces according to some. Based on Spring Street, the tiny house also has a pocket-sized kitchen-living area and a petite en-suite bathroom, reports the Manchester Evening News.And while this might not seem like anything out of the ordinary, the interior of the property has got people talking online - all because of the dimensions. title: man claims holiday inn hotel
story: Man claims Holiday Inn hotel had dirty clothes behind bed and decomposing food on floorHoliday Inn admits there was a clear lapse in standards after David Craig was disgusted by the state of his hotel room and feared it had not been cleaned for some timeThe Holiday Inn Express in InvernessByJon BradyReporterGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA man was appalled at what he claims was the state of his Holiday Inn hotel room which contained decomposing food on the floor, dust and an item of dirty clothing behind the bed.David Craig wanted to catch up with pals and booked into for an overnight stay at the Holiday Inn Express but he was disgusted after he made the gross discovery behind the bed in his room, the Daily Record reports.The -year-old mechanic found what he says were a dirty pair of womenaposs underwear after he moved the bed to retrieve his car keys. Decomposing bits of food were also strewn across the floor in addition to a layer of dust which suggested it hadnapost been cleaned for some time, David claims.He says hotel staff were apologetic but he worries rooms are not being deep cleaned amidst the Covid- pandemic. David told the Record: We booked a few nights away in Inverness to see some old friends and on the morning of January  I dropped my keys down the back of the bed, where the headboard is. I pulled the bed out and there was a dirty pair of ladiesapos underwear and there was also bits of food and a disgusting amount of dust. You could see it clearly hadnapost been touched in a while. We certainly didnapost expect a room like this, especially with the virus going round. The website of the hotel in Inverness, Scotland, promises daily housekeeping as part of its services.  And a statement from parent company IHG on the webpage promises: IHG has a long-standing commitment to rigorous cleaning procedures. However, David remains concerned that hotels arenapost giving rooms a proper clean in between guests. He added: The hotel staff were apologetic and switched our room and let us stay for nothing. That doesnapost bother us but people need to know whataposs going on in hotels. That area of the room has just totally been ignored. If it had been lovely and clean behind the bed and we found a pair of underwear you would think it might be a one-off. But it was clear the bed hadnapost been moved for a while. It ruined the rest of our stay. Youaposd expect to find the room completely clean, especially now.. A spokesman for the Holiday Inn Express said: Overall, the Holiday Inn Express Inverness has an excellent record for cleanliness however on this occasion there was a clear lapse in standards. The hotel apologised to the guest regarding this matter, which was immediately rectied directly with the guest. news uk-news omicron-cold--simple-steps-"Doctor gives tips to relieve covid- omicron symptomsByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Jan | commentsAs the winter weather continues and temperatures plummet, many of us are falling ill to seasonal illnesses.With many of the symptoms of the Omicron Covid iant similar to a cold, it can be hard for Brits to know the dference.The symptoms of the new iant are slightly dferent from others such as Delta, and it’s incredibly important to get tested, especially as they can be mild.The most common symptoms we associate with coronavirus is a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss of taste and smell, according to the official list on the NHS website.But with Omicron people are being warned to be vigilant of other classic cold symptoms, such as headaches, sore throats and sneezing. Professor Spector from the ZOE Covid app said data suggests about half of all cases of Delta are being missed because people are only on the lookout for the “classic” Covid symptoms. Do I have Omicron or a cold  The Omicron iant has many symptoms that are similar to the common cold. According to ZOE data scientists, the top five symptoms of Omicron are:Runny nose Headache FatigueSneezing Sore throat According to the NHS, the most common cold symptoms are:A blocked or runny nose A sore throat Headaches Coughs Sneezing A raised temperature Pressure in your ears and face Loss of taste and smellWith many of the symptoms overlapping, there is no guaranteed way to tell the dference without a test. Professor Spector said: For most people, an Omicron positive case will feel much more like the common cold, starting with a sore throat, runny nose and a headache. You only need to ask a friend who has recently tested positive to find this out. We need to change public messaging urgently to save lives. The safest thing to do, and the only way to know for sure, is to get a PCR testyou have any of these symptoms. You can book a test for free on the NHS website. What to do while you wait for your test results  Dr Habil Khorakiwala, founder and chair of Wockhardt Group, has uploaded a video where he shares six things you can do at home while you wait for your PCR test result. He explains: There are six simple precautions which you may take, and may certainly help in preventing the infection and definitely reduces the severity of symptoms, especially of Omicron.  These are as follows: Step one – gargle with warm salt water Gargle deeply with warm salt water, or a medical mouthwash, three to four times a day. This has been proven in several studies to reduce the saliva viral load for several hours. Step two – steam inhalation Steam inhalation can help ease your symptoms, whether it be a cold or Covid. This is a great trick to soothe and open nasal passages when suffering from a cold or sinus infection. Dr Khorakiwala recommends doing this two to three times a day.  Step three – avoid cold drinks Dr Khorakiwala recommends avoiding drinking cold and chilled beverages. However, itaposs important to stay hydrated, so Dr Khorakiwala recommends drinking hot water frequently. Step four – breathing exercises Dr Khorakiwala recommends practising some form of breathing exercises, such as deep breathing, for at least five minutes a day. Step five – physical exercise Try to do  to  minutes of physical activity daily. Those who arenapost able to do that much should do as much as possible without overexerting themselves. Step six – remember to wear a mask Most importantly, Dr Khorakiwala says we should wear the right-fitting mask properly. He says to only use three-ply surgical masks or N masks. Dr Khorakiwala continued: Avoid common cloth masks and fancy design masks. If necessary, use them only as a double mask over the recommended mask. title: plenty fish monster who used
story: Plenty of Fish monster posed as doctor to control girlfriends le for two yearsCruel and manipulative Carwyn Roberts, , developed a tangled web of lies to control and torment his girlfriend. Using fake email addresses, he convinced her shed been drugged and sexually abused in her own home, and that they had bought a house togetherCarwyn Roberts used fake email addresses to torment and control his girlfriend Image: WALES NEWS SERVICEByJason EvansRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A cruel and manipulative man used fake email addresses and  identities to control his girlfriendaposs le – even convincing her sheaposd been drugged and sexually abused in her own home.Carwyn Roberts, , created fake identities of people in positions of trust, like doctors and lawyers, to spin a web of lies which ranged from the couple buying a house together to convincing the vulnerable woman she was pregnant. He also persuaded her to leave her job at a school by telling her heaposd secured her a new role with the local council. Mold Crown Court heard this week how Roberts subjected his victim to years of torment, which has had a devastating effect on her mental health.Jade Tufail, prosecuting, told the court how Roberts and his victim met on the dating website Plenty of Fish in  and immediately got along. Soon the defendant moved into her flat in Bangor and the relationship was described as amazing with the womanaposs young daughter referring to the defendant as daddy Carwyn. The court heard the womanaposs previous relationship had ended acrimoniously and had left her in a bad way – including engaging in self-harming – and she told her new boyfriend about these issues. The prosecutor said Roberts told the woman he had found out he was was inheriting £, from his grandfatheraposs brother and he would use the money to buy their dream home. The couple went to view houses and settled on one in a new Redrow development in Bangor, and Roberts said his familyaposs solicitors would handle all the legal work. In fact there was no money and there was no family lawyer doing the conveyancing work, and the emails the woman began receiving about the house purchase were being sent by her partner from a bogus account he had set up. This was to be the start of months of cruel deception perpetrated by the defendant. The court heard Roberts then began to tell his partner he was receiving prank calls from people claiming she was being unfaithful and that the solicitor was looking into who was sending them. As the weeks progressed the fake solicitor said he had found out that there were hidden cameras in her flat which had filmed her having sex with men, and he began to quiz her about her sex le. The woman was adamant no such activity had taken place but Roberts, through the bogus solicitor, told her the reason she couldnapost remember what had happened was because she had been drugged before being sexually abused and that the police were now involved. Miss Tufail said while this was going on the defendant created another fake person, this time a woman by the name of Amanda Davies who supposedly worked with him in the local authority, who also began emailing his partner. His victim was persuaded by Amanda Davies to give up her employment in a local school with the promise of job in the council, and Roberts even came home with a work badge in his partneraposs name along with training and induction materials. Again this was all a lie. Then one day the fake council email account contacted the victim to say her partner had been drugged at work in a leisure centre in Caernarfon by an associate of her ex-boyfriend. Over the following days further emails were sent, supposed containing information from a nurse, saying the drugging incident had affected Robertsapos sperm and he would now not be able to have children. The court heard how the victim broke down crying at this news as she had wanted a child with the defendant. The Amanda Davies email account then started giving the woman instructions about having sex with Roberts in order to maximise their chances of conceiving. Meanwhile the charade about the purchase of non-existent house was still continuing and even went so far as the victim, her daughter, and the defendant packing up their possessions ready for the move. Miss Tufail said that by this point the victim had effectively been brainwashed into doing whatever the people in the emails told her to do.The months of lying culminated with Roberts coming home one day with an ultrasound scan showing a pregnancy with twins and telling his partner she was pregnant.This was followed-up by emails from a doctor sent from yet another bogus account he had created. It later transpired the defendant had carried out extensive internet searches in order to obtain a fake ultrasound image. The court heard the victim was confused about the scan and emails from the doctor confirming her pregnancy but the couple went to see her brother to tell the family the happy news. It was the brotheraposs partner who spotted something was amiss with the scan and raised the alarm. The police were contacted and an investigation uncovered the full extent of the defendantaposs deceit. In his first interview the -year-old defendant claimed he had his partner had been duped by somebody  but in his second interview he changed his story and said he, in fact, was the victim of domestic abuse at the hands of his partner. In a statement from the partner which was read to the court she explained the impact the months of lies had had on her. She said she felt ashamed and manipulated and said Roberts had been aware of her vulnerabilities and had exploited every single one of them. Carwyn Grfith Roberts, of Cae Llyn, Llanaelhaearn, Caernarfon, had previously pleaded guilty on the day of trial to engaging in controlling or coercive behaviour in an intimate or family relationship when he appeared in the dock for sentencing. He has no previous convictions. Richard Edwards, for Roberts, said at the time of the offending the defendant was conscious of his own perceived inadequacies and wanted to make himself look better in the eyes of his partner. However matters escalated and – in his clientaposs own words – the lies got bigger and bigger. The barrister said Roberts was taking part in counselling to address the issues in his le and added that he was now in a new relationship with someone who aware of the court case and who was supportive of him. Judge Niclas Parry told Roberts thatthe offending were not so serious people hearing the bizarre facts of the case would be rendered incredulous. He told the defendant he had taken advantage of a vulnerable woman to control her le, adding: Your conduct was as cruel as it was manipulative and despicable. With a % discount for his guilty plea Roberts was sentenced to two years in prison suspended for two years and was ordered to complete a rehabilitation course and  hours of unpaid work. He must also pay £, towards prosecution costs. The defendant was made the subject of a lelong restraining order banning him from contacting his former partner or posting anything about her on social media. Speaking after the hearing Rhian Jones, senior crown prosecutor with the Crown Prosecution Servicein Wales, said: The level of manipulation that Carwyn Roberts exerted on his partner is quite staggering and the effect on her mental health must have been awful. The CPS were able to build a strong case showing the number of fake accounts and emails could be traced back to him, demonstrating he had told lie after lie. The victim can take comfort in knowing that Roberts is now paying for the horrendous ordeal he put her through and we hope this helps her move forward with her le. The Duke of Sussex’s unprecedented move of threatening to sue the government is both breathtaking and utterly baffling. Those in royal circles have almost universally questioned the play at hand, not only in its nature but equally in execution. True enough, with his background in the military and his position in one of the most famous families in the world – and celebrity lestyle – Prince Harry and his family are arguably high profile targets. TV screens are awash with adverts showing us how easy it is to change your hair colour. Home hair dye kits allow you to cover your gray hair, change your hair to a lighter or darker hue and for the more adventurous you can go all out with brightly-coloured barnet. But for one hapless student her mission to become a blonde out of a bottle went drastically at home - her hair snapped off.Mortied Sienna Oliver took to TikTok to show the horric results of her botched DIY job. Last week a woman said her hair was ‘ruined’ after a trip to the salon where her stylist blamed her damaged locks on climate change. When she left she was delighted with the bright result and showed off her new look on her social media sites. But her joy turned to horror the next day when she washed it and said her tresses became so brittle it snapped in half as she touched it, reported the Daily Star. When she contacted her beautician she was told a possible cause of her ruined look was climate change. story: UKs most wanted:  British fugitives on the run in Spain named by policeThe Most Wanted campaign is a joint initiative between Britains National Crime Agency, Crimestoppers, and Spanish Police, which targets alleged drug lords, murder suspects and underworld armourers for capture after they fled to SpainMark Roberts, , is wanted over the violent attempted robbery of a £, watch that left the victim with a collapsed lung Image: PAByTom PettorCrime Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Twelve most-wanted British fugitives on the run in Spain have today been named by police. They include alleged drug kingpins, two suspects wanted for murder and underworld armourers.The hit list was released as part of the Most Wanted campaign — a joint initiative between the National Crime Agency, Crimestoppers and Spanish police. Steve Rodhouse, the NCA’s Director General of Operations, said at the launch in Madrid on Wednesday: “Spain is not a safe haven. “We have a brilliant relationship with the country’s ious law enforcement agencies and work together daily to protect the public. “With  offenders arrested in our last fugitives campaign, criminals know we will never give up and we’re never far behind them. He said the Spanish authorities arrested and ed more than  wanted UK fugitives last year. Mr Rodhouse added: “Many of these fugitives will be trying to blend in to the large British communities who have made their homes in Spain, andyou are resident, you may know one of them from your town or village. “Loyalties change over time and we urge anyone with information about these men to help us find them.”The Wanted Dozen Nana OppongOppong, , is wanted by Essex Police for the drive-by murder of grandfather Robert Powell, , who was shot eight times with a mm pistol on  June . It is alleged that the victim and Powell were from rival criminal factions.  Jack MayleHeavily tattooed Mayle, , is suspected of supplying Class A drug MDMA and other illegal substances. Mayle is wanted for running a drug line in south London and allegedly working with a dark web drugs supplier. When he fled, Mayle, who is from Croydon in south London, had a tattooed neck, a diamond tattoo under his left eye and ‘Croydon’ inked on the outside of his left forearm. He may have tried to alter his appearance and is known to carry weapons.Callum HalpinHalpin, , is wanted by Greater Manchester Police for the murder of drug dealer Luke Graham, , and the attempted murder of Anton Verigotta.Graham, a dad-of-two, was ambushed and shot dead in a drugs turf war in broad daylight on a street in Ashton-under-Lyne as children played nearby in June . story: We both had our drinks spiked on dferent nights out - and we were stealth injectedRhianna Poots and Sara Begic who respectively witnessed and experienced stealth injections and drink spiking are sharing their stories in the hope they can save others from the same experience and Sara Begichope to raise awareness of spiking in Newcastle by sharing their ordeal" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Rhianna-Poots-and-Sara-Begic.jpg" width"" "" Rhianna Pootsand Sara Begichope to raise awareness of spiking in Newcastle by sharing their ordeal Image: Rhianna Poots and Sara BegicBySophie Brownson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Twoteenagerswho claim they had theirdrinks spikedand were injected on two dferent nights out are now describing the terrying ordeals, which left one woman worried about going out.Rhianna Poots and Sara Begic have said they are sharing their stories in the hope they can save others from the same experience.They are sharing their stories in the wake of anepidemic of drink-spiking reportsfrom around the UK in recent months.The majority of the victims to come forward across the UK have been young women, mostly students, but there are also some young men who have reported similar cases. Rhianna was enjoying out in a bar in Newcastle city centre on January  when three of her female friends suddenly became unwell. The Northumbria University student said two of the group, who had been sharing the same drink, started to be violently sick at the venue - with one even needing to be carried out by a bouncer.Speaking to Chronicle Live , -year-old Rhianna said: When we got home their breathing was raspy and their eyes were dilated.  They could all hear what I was saying to them but they couldnapost make sense of it. Rhianna took her friends to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Gateshead as they became increasingly unwell. I called an ambulance as [my friend] Sara [Begic] was especially bad, she said. Her breathing wasnapost right, she was hyperventilating. She wasnapost responding and going in and out of consciousness. They werenapost any ambulances available but they said aposyou need to get her to hospital now.apos All three women underwent tests to see whether they had been spiked. Rhianna said they are still waiting on the results. Sara Begic, , from Durham, believes her drink was spiked during the incident and is now worried about going out again following her ordeal. The Northumbria University law student said: It was horrible. The last thing I remember is sitting with my friends. I knew where I was but I just couldnapost do anything. I couldnapost move my body and the bouncer carried me out. I feel quite unsafe going out now. The group of friends revealed that this isnapost actually the first time they believe they have been spiked while on a night out in the city. One of the students, who did not want to be named, said she was spiked by an injection in her leg on December . She became ill later that night and went to hospital to be checked out the following morning. I felt like I had been possessed and my body felt freezing, she said. It was like I couldn’t physically stop myself from shaking it was probably the worst experience of my le. I don’t feel completely safe going back out again. Rhianna said the friends reported the injection spiking incident to the police but believed that the venue had been unable to help officers because of its poor CCTV footage. As a result, they decided not to report the second incident, which happened at the same venue. However, the friends hope that sharing their story will encourage others to be vigilant when on a night out. Just because people have stopped posting about [spiking] doesnapost mean that it isnapost still happening, Rhianna said. Northumbria Police confirmed that an investigation is ongoing into the reported injection spiking incident and stressed that dedicated officers are on patrol to ensure the city remains a safe place for a night out.A Northumbria Police spokeswoman said: We can confirm we have received a report from a woman concerned she had been spiked with an injection while on a night out in Newcastle on December . “An investigation has been launched and enquiries into this incident are ongoing.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Northumbria PoliceCCTVCCTV footageTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Weve introduced a four-day working week, staff deserve more time offAs a number of UK companies trial employees working a four-day week, in order to measure whether employees are more productive, one Scottish firm has told how it is transforming their livesByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA Scottish distillery has told how they introduced a four-day week for staff in a bid to boost their wellbeing. Owners of The Isle of Barra Distillers decided to shorten the working week in a bid to offer workers more flexibility. The company says it hopes to give its tightly-knit team the opportunity to spend more time with loved ones and spend less time and money commuting. Ahead of the change, which began this month, employees agreed to work the same hours over fewer days - with people opting to work an extra two hours each sht. They have switched up their operation to make the transition work - meaning that orders are no longer being dispatched on a Friday. Being on Barra, itaposs not so easy to get away without booking holidays so it lets staff travel to the mainland without hassle. title: woman cant grieve after council
story: Woman cant grieve after council breaks in to clear her home instead of dead mumsSharon Jackson, , from Stoke-on-Trent, claims the local council switched off her electricity and broke in to her home after her address was mixed up with her late mums, who died at the start of DecemberSharon Jackson says the councils actions have left her unable to grieve for her mums death Image: Stoke SentinelByAimi RedfernPeter DiamondRyan Fahey:,  Jan | comments A woman mourning the death of her mum says a series of blunders made by the local council have left her unable to grieve.Sharon Jackson, , claims council workers forced themselves into her home in Stoke-on-Trent after the death of her mother because they were wrongly told it needed to be cleared.But more distress came later when Sharonaposs gas and electricity were cut off - because the council told British Gas the house was unoccupied. The -year-old says the two major mix-ups have caused a heavy burden of stress, leaving her unable to properly grieve for her late mum, Stoke-on-TrentLive reports. Sharon informed Stoke-on-Trent City council after her beloved motheraposs death on December  and cleared the home.She ed the keys to the authority in a letter that clearly stated the address, she claims.  At the bottom, she included her own address in nearby Dale Avenue and contact details, as requested, in case there were any queries, according to Stoke-on-Trent Live. On December , Sharon was dumbfounded to received a phone call from a friend while she was at work, stating that council workers had forced their way into her home. She said: I was at work when I got a phone call, and I was getting lots of messages, saying the council were breaking into my house. I had to leave work and go home to find they had broken in through the front door. Apparently they had been told that I had done a moonlight flit and the house was empty. There were three vans outside. They had been traipsing though the house. My friend had told they they had the wrong address. By the time I got back, they had gone. The front door handle was all loose because they hadnapost fixed it properly. I felt unsafe in my own house after  years of living there. Sharon, who lives at the property with her -year-old son Reece, contacted Stoke-on-Trent City Council after the mix-up. She said: The woman I spoke to couldnapost apologise enough. They sent me a bunch of flowers and said they would compensate me for the time I lost at work, although I havenapost received that yet.  But it shouldnapost have happened in the first place. I canapost understand how the council could get the address wrong. Thinking that was the end of the matter, Sharon was at home watching TV on January  when her electricity and gas suddenly went off. When she spoke to British Gas, she was told the council had informed them her property was empty. She said: At first I thought it was a power cut but when I looked out I saw it was only my house. I rang British Gas and explained what had happened and they said I had been cut off.  She said they were told by the council in December that the house was empty and the account had been closed. I have had to open a new account to get it sorted out.Sharon, who works at Jackmark Engineering in Longport, says the situation has made what is already an upsetting time even worse.Iaposve not had time to grieve over my mum because Iaposve been so busy sorting out the councilaposs mess. Iaposm a nervous wreck and Iaposm crying all the time.It has been one phone call after another trying to sort out whataposs going on. Iaposve even rung Severn Trent to make sure my water isnapost going to be cut off as well. Iaposm disgusted by the councilaposs ineptitude. A city council spokesman said: Firstly, we would like to extend our deepest sympathies to Sharon and her family for their loss at this very dficult time. We have , council properties and regrettably a genuine administrative mistake was made on this occasion that incorrectly listed the tenancy for ending, which resulted in a lock change being arranged. As part of that process, utility companies are automatically notied at the same time. However, we appreciate this shouldnapost have happened and we have spoken to Sharon and apologised unreservedly. We have also told her we will also cover any financial costs incurred. title: young woman ms facing eviction
story: Young woman with MS facing eviction with her two dogs after gran dies of CovidCaitlin Paul had been living with her gran Elizabeth, , on and off for five years before the pensioner died of coronavirus, days before it killed her son-in-law tooCaitlin Paul is  and has MS. She was her grans main carer Image: Reach plcByKaitlin EastonReporterKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A grieving woman who has MS is facing homelessness after being told she must leave the council home she lived in with her gran before she died of Covid. Caitlin Paul had been living with her gran Elizabeth, , on and off for five years before the pensioner was admitted to hospital with sepsis in February . The -year-old moved into her granaposs Glasgow council flat permanently to look after her beloved dog Buddy while she spent  months recovering in hospital and re-learning basic motor skills.Caitlin became her granaposs main carer when she was discharged from hospital on November ,  and the OAP was given a new wheelchair adapted home by Cadder Housing. The pair planned to put Caitlin on the tenancy agreement so she was officially on documentation but tragically Elizabeth caught Covid just days after being discharged from hospital. She died a short time later before the tenancy documents could be updated. Are you facing eviction unfairly  Email webnews@mirror Caitlin, who suffers from MS, will be evicted from the house tomorrow and has nowhere to go, leaving her homeless with two dogs.She told the Daily Record : Me and my gran were really close so I stayed with her all the time. Last year she was unwell and had sepsis so I had to phone an ambulance and she was taken into hospital.We got a call saying she wouldnapost make it through the night and then another call the night after that, but she did. She was in hospital for  months and lost all her mobility. She had to re-learn how to feed herself but she did - she was amazing.  She was a tenant in a flat with Cadder Housing but they offered her a specially adapted home when she was in hospital. I got the house ready for her coming home, and decorated it so it was nice and fresh. We had lots of balloons up for the day she got out of hospital. I even had a sausage sandwich ready for her as she hadnapost had one in ages.The family had a small gathering to welcome Elizabeth into her new home but tragically days later Elizabeth, Caitlin, her mum Deborah, auntie Jacqui, sister Beth and uncle George, all tested positive for coronavirus. Caitlin said: She got out of hospital and then we caught Covid three days later. My gran was ok at first, but a few nights later she went downhill and I had to phone an ambulance. She didnapost want to go into hospital. She was really upset and scared she wouldnapost get back out. But it was the best place for her as she needed oxygen. On Monday, November  my gran was told she was getting on Tuesday and an ambulance had been arranged to bring her home. That night she took a turn for the worst. The hospital called and told me to go up, but when I arrived to see her she wasnapost herself. We just had to sit with her until she died.  Elizabeth died in the early hours of Tuesday November  at Glasgow Royal Infirmary after her lung collapsed due to Covid complications. Tragedy struck again when Caitlinaposs uncle George - Elizabethaposs son-in-law - died from coronavirus in the same hospital on November  just four days later. The devastated family were left to plan two funerals and fork out thousands of pounds. Caitlin began to fear for her future as she was never added to her granaposs tenancy agreement. Less than three weeks after her granaposs sudden death, she met with Cadder Housing and on December  she was told their hands were tied and she was given three weeks to evict the property.  Caitlin was then admitted to hospital with MS and Cadder gave her an extension until January . I completely understand Iaposm not on the tenancy agreement but we never thought anything like this would happen, Caitlin said. I never wanted to stay here permanently, as Iaposm not in a wheelchair and the house could go to someone  who needs it. I only wanted to stay here until I had somewhere  to go. They told me to contact Shelter Scotland and said they had been trying to get me temporary accommodation through the council. My MS has got worse with the stress and so has my mental health. I havenapost even had time to grieve the loss of my gran and my uncle. I felt like they could have at least said you can stay until you find somewhere  to go. They didnapost even offer to help with storage. Caitlin now faces sleeping on her auntieaposs couch after she is evicted and has nowhere to move into full-time.Her sister, brothers and cousins have now set up a fundraising page to try and pay for temporary accommodation so Caitlin has somewhere to live.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mental healthHomelessnessCoronavirusMultiple sclerosisSepsisHousing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman travelled 500 miles take
story: Woman travelled  miles to take UKs easiest driving test and failedConstance Kampfner travelled  miles, from London to the Isle of Mull in search of the UKs easiest driving test - but sadly she failed againConstance wanted to give herself the best chance of passing her test Image: PAByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments Regardless of whether you passed on your first go, or youaposre one of the unlucky ones who took six attempts - youaposve got to admit, driving tests are hard.And, while every driving test is required to feature a host of dferent things, they obviously dfer depending on which part of the country youaposre taking it in. So, when one woman failed her first driving test in her native London, instead of re-booking locally, she decided to travel approximately  miles to the Isle of Mull, just off the west coast of Scotland, in search of the UKaposs aposeasiestapos test. Constance Kampfner spent  hours travelling north, by car and ferry, having handpicked the test route after discovering it only consisted of one roundabout her biggest fear. However, on arrival, she struggled to find a single driving instructor willing to take her for her test, forcing her to turn to Facebook in desperation. I was determined I would pass my driving test the second time - I simply needed to optimise my chances. A quick Google search told me where I needed to go, the Isle of Mull. I booked for the earliest available date, in mid-December, she told The Times. For their lessons residents tend to head to Oban on the mainland, where the ferry to the island departs from. None of the instructors I got hold of fancied the trip, each warning me of high chances that my crossing would be cancelled in bad weather. I took to Facebook, where local paramedic Mairi took pity and offered her blue Mini.Constance was feeling confident, especially after learning Mullaposs single roundabout would not feature on her test and there was nowhere to parallel park - not to mention the stunning local scenery which glistened under the winter sun. When they got back onto the mainland, the test instructor told her: I don’t like to talk about people who fail their tests. Think of it as just not passing. Better luck next time, Constance.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. extent of the destruction that has been wrought on the islands with hundreds of homes washed away.At least three people have been killed from the volcanic eruption and tsunami that struck last Saturday which the Tonga government has called an unprecedented disaster.Photos show shocked people looking at the horror caused with homes and livelihoods destroyed. Waves reaching up to  metres hit the outer Haaposapia island group, destroying all of the houses on the island of Mango, as well as the west coast of Tongaaposs main island, Tongatapu, the prime ministeraposs office said. In Kanokupolu village on the island of Tongatapu locals have been pictured staring at trees that have been felled, buildings in ruins and everything coated in black ash. James Garvin, chief scientist at NASAaposs Goddard Space Flight Center, said the force of the eruption was estimated to be equivalent to five to  megatons of TNT, an explosive force more than  times the nuclear bomb dropped by the United States on Hiroshima, Japan, at the end of World War Two. The blast was heard as far away as Alaska and was probably one of the loudest events to occur on Earth in over a century, according to Michael Poland, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey.This might be the loudest eruption since [the eruption of the Indonesian volcano] Krakatau in , Poland told NPR. That massive th-century eruption killed thousands and released so much ash that it cast much of the region into darkness. Hunga Tonga-Hunga Haaposapai was completely destroyed by Saturdayaposs explosion, says Dan Slayback, a research scientist for NASAaposs Goddard, as well as Science Systems and Applications Inc. Slayback says the blast was so massive it even appears to have taken chunks out of the older islands nearby. They werenapost ash — they were solid rock, blown to bits, he says. It was quite amazing to see that happen.  With its airport smothered by volcanic ash and communications badly hampered by the severing of an undersea cable, information on the scale of the devastation has mostly come from reconnaissance aircraft. Planes sent from New Zealand show the damage from the air with images of the inundation caused by tsunami on the western coast of the main island of Tongatapu.  A dficult humanitarian aid effort is now under way to help the survivors from the disaster. The Red Cross said its teams in Tonga had confirmed that salt water from the tsunami and volcanic ash were polluting the drinking water relied on by tens of thousands of people. Securing access to safe drinking water is a critical immediate priority... as there is a mounting risk of diseases such as cholera and diarrhoea, Katie Greenwood, the Pacic head of delegation for the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, said in a statement. story: Incredible moment enormous super-yacht scrapes under bridge with inches to spareDutch shipbuilders Heesen had to be inch perfect as they transported the m super-yacht MY Galactica from where it was constructed, in the Netherlands, to the North SeaThe super-yacht MY Galactica missed one bridge by just cm Image: Scott Hampton   Heesen   SWNSByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA super-yacht has been pictured scraping under a low bridge with just cm to spare as it made its way to the sea.Dutch shipbuilders Heesen had to transport the m boat MY Galactica from its shed in Oss, in the Netherlands, to the North Sea in a journey that takes up to four months to prepare. The luxury yacht, whose price is confidential, could also be seen narrowly getting through river locks - where the slightest error could cost a fortune.Heesen spokeswoman Sara Gioanola said that it takes three or four months to plan a voyage due to the permits and certicates needed. We are used to taking our boats to the North Sea via canals and rivers - weaposve been doing so for the past + years, she said. After four years of construction, Heesenaposs -metre all-aluminium Project Cosmos, now known as MY Galactica, left her shed in Oss last Friday and began her maiden voyage through the Dutch canals and rivers in perfect weather conditions.No Heesen has ever been so celebrated when leaving our shipyard. Passing through the tight lock in Macharen on Saturday, with only  cm of clearance on each side, we had to wait for a calm day with no wind. Locks are not the only gateways we have to go through.  We must also pass under many bridges, where clearance is particularly tight. Beforehand, we perform physical measurements. These are paramount, especially now that the river waters are higher than usual. She added: Weaposve been doing so for the past + years. This is standard procedure with luxury yachts of this size when dealing with inland cruising. Waiting for the tide to fall is just aposbusiness as usualapos. Galactica passed Heusden with  cm clearance.  Arthur Brouwer, Heesen CEO, said: Building large and complex superyachts is exciting, both from an engineering and construction perspective. We are incredibly fortunate to have the best naval architects, engineers, and craftsmen in the country to build our yachts. In spite of all the challenges imposed by the pandemic.  We also managed to keep the construction of Project Cosmos, now known as MY Galactica, on schedule - which was no mean feat. Precision aluminium construction, high performance, and the finest Dutch craftsmanship are steeped into the DNA of this shipyard. Cosmos is the ultimate expression of our ability to build daring projects that stretch the imagination of its engineers and craftspeople. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details.
